shortdesc.ph: Provides statistics of the remote video stream.
Statistics of the remote video stream.

plentry.pd: User ID of the remote user sending the video stream.
Video delay (ms). @deprecated In audio-video sync scenarios, you can use networkTransportDelay and jitterBufferDelay from to get video delay data.
End-to-end video delay (ms), from the time the remote user captures the video to when the local user receives and renders it.
Video width (pixels).
Video height (pixels).
Bitrate (Kbps) of the received remote video since the last report.
Input frame rate (fps) for decoding the remote video.
Output frame rate (fps) after decoding the remote video.
Output frame rate (fps) of the rendered remote video.
Frame loss rate (%) of the remote video.
Packet loss rate (%) of the remote video after applying anti-packet-loss techniques.
Video stream type. See .

Total duration (ms) of video freeze after the remote user joins the channel. In video calls with frame rates no lower than 5 fps, if the interval between two renderable video frames exceeds 500 ms, it is considered a video freeze.

Percentage (%) of video freeze duration relative to the total available video time. Video is considered available if the remote user has not stopped sending video or disabled the video module after joining the channel.
Time (ms) that audio leads video. If this value is negative, it means audio lags behind video.
Total active time (ms) of the video. Video is considered available if the remote user or host has not stopped sending video or disabled the video module after joining the channel.
Total duration (ms) of the remote video stream.

Video quality score of the remote stream during the reporting interval, calculated using Agoraâ€™s real-time video MOS (Mean Opinion Score) algorithm. The value ranges from [0, 500]. Divide by 100 to get the MOS score, ranging from 0 to 5. Higher scores indicate better video quality. For texture video data, this parameter always returns 0.
Total number of received video bytes (bytes), including FEC bytes, aggregated.
User ID of the remote user sending the video stream.
This field is deprecated. In audio-video sync scenarios, you can get video delay data through networkTransportDelay and jitterBufferDelay in . Video delay (ms).
End-to-end video delay (ms), which is the time from video capture by the remote user to video rendering by the local user.
Video width (pixels).
Video height (pixels).
Bitrate (Kbps) of the remote video received since the last statistics update.
Frame rate (fps) of the decoded remote video.
Frame rate (fps) of the rendered remote video.
Frame loss rate (%) of the remote video.
Packet loss rate (%) of the remote video after applying anti-packet-loss techniques.

Video stream type:
0: High-quality stream, i.e., high-resolution high-bitrate video stream.
1: Low-quality stream, i.e., low-resolution low-bitrate video stream.

Total duration (ms) of remote video stalling after the remote user joins the channel. Video is considered stalled when the frame rate is not lower than 5 fps and the interval between two renderable frames exceeds 500 ms.

Percentage (%) of total stalling time over the total available video time. As long as the remote user continues sending video after joining the channel and does not disable video, the video is considered available.
Time (ms) that audio leads video. If this value is negative, audio lags behind video.

Total available duration (ms) of the video. As long as the remote user or host continues sending video after joining the channel and does not disable the video module, the video is considered available.
Total duration (ms) of the remote video stream.

Quality of the remote video stream during the reporting interval. This value is calculated using Agora's real-time video MOS (Mean Opinion Score) method, ranging from [0, 500]. Divide by 100 to get the MOS score (0 to 5), where a higher score indicates better quality. For texture video data, this parameter always returns 0.
Total number of video bytes received (bytes).
